subject: Re: [junit] Our tests are not compatibel with JUnit 3.8.1, why?
msgSnippet: I try to explain it in a different way. Please look at this: import junit.framework.TestCase; import org.junit.Test; public class MyTest extends TestCase {
messageBody:
I try to explain it in a different way. Please look at this:

import junit.framework.TestCase;
import org.junit.Test;

public class MyTest extends TestCase {
@Test
public void foo() {
}

}

When I start this test, I get this error message: junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: No tests found in MyTest

I run it on Eclipse 3.3 M4 with JUnit 4.2 in classpath.

As soon as I remove "extends TestCase", the test runs with no error! But this behaviour is deadly for migrating from JUnit 3 to JUnit 4!

I don't believe that Beck and Gamma did cause such migration problems. Or did they? If not, what is the solution?


David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
Hans,

There may be ways to do what you want. I'd like to be sure I know
what that is, though. It sounds like you'd like to use JUnit 4 to run
JUnit 3 tests, but having the @Ignore annotation observed. Is this
true? Are there other features you'd like to be able to use? Thanks,

David Saff

On 1/23/07, hans_schwaebli <hans_schwaebli@...> wrote:
> Our old JUnit tests are written for JUnit 3.8.1.
>
> They first extended TestCase. After we introduced JMock, all our
> TestCases extend MockObjectTestCase.
>
> This is because we extend from our own JUnit test helper class which
> extends from MockObjectTestCase.
>
> Now we use the .jar file from JUnit 4.2 and JMock 1.1.
>
> But only if we write new tests, which don't extend MockObjectTestCase
> and TestCase and insert the method below for Eclipse 3.1.2, the tests
> are run as JUnit 4 tests. Otherwise they are run as JUnit 3 tests.
>
> public static junit.framework.Test suite()
> {
> return new JUnit4TestAdapter(MyTest.class);
> }
>
> It would be much work to refactor our old test. I thought it would be
> easy to use the new JUnit 4 features on them like @Ignore.
>
> Why are our tests always run as JUnit 3 tests if they extend from
> TestCase? Does anyone has a solution for us for using the new JUnit 4
> features without refactoring our tests very much?
>
>
